text: my friends I'm Rachna and I'm back with
a new lesson well today's lesson is all
about the difference between small and
little now the other day when I went to
class I asked a few students is there a
difference between small and little or
is it all they both mean the same on
they can be used interchangeably so a
few of them told me that there is a
small difference between small and
little and some told me there is a
little difference between small and
little well in today's lesson you're
going to learn how to use small and
little correctly alright so let's start
now I have an example here John is small
for his age so when I say John is small
for his age that means he's short he's
not taken up to much height as per his
age all right
so here we use small to indicate when
you or when you talk about height or
size of a person well sometimes we also
say I wear a small size shirt try to
have small medium large and Excel so you
always a small size you do not see a
little size so you say small size many
times we talk about really short people
or petite people being as small built so
we talk about this size or the height
all right now let's take a look at
little Mary is a little girl well now if
I say Mary is a small girl that would
again mean she's short not too tall for
her age but when I say Mary is a little
girl here I mean she is young all right
I'm sure you remember that poem or the
nursery rhyme we learnt in school mary
had a little lamb so that means a young
lamb so when we use little we mean the
person is young
all right I am sure this is clear to you
let's move on I have a small amount of
money now your money is an uncountable
noun we cannot count money I cannot say
have five money six money can I know we
need a medium in this case it's a
currency so I have five dollars or have
ten pounds so it needs a medium to be
measured so money is uncountable so the
important thing to remember here is when
you talk about uncountable nouns using
small always use small amount for the
uncountable nouns right I cannot say I
have a small money would it make sense
no
so always say I have a small amount of
money all right
now your I can replace it by saying I
have a little money
so again money is uncountable remember
little is he always used with
uncountable nouns all right so I have a
little money your you needn't use I have
a little amount of money just say I have
a little money and that's fine remember
small amount for uncountable nouns and a
little for uncountable nouns all right
the next sentence a small number of
people came to work now people is the
noun you're comfortable right you can
say five people ten people so it is a
countable noun so you always say a small
number use number for countable nouns
you cannot say small people came to work
so you always say a small number of
people came to work remember small
number for countable notes and the
example here I had little trouble with
my car can you count trouble fight
trouble six trouble no its uncountable
so here we need to remember little is
always used for uncountable nouns never
for countable nouns all right Mary is
smaller than Kimberly all right now you
are using small in its comparative form
can I say Mary is littler than Kimberly
no little has no comparative or
superlative form so we say Mary is
smaller than Kimberly all right in the
next sentence Mary is the smallest in
the class now this is the comparative
and this is the superlative so again I
cannot say Mary is the littlest in the
class because little has no comparative
or superlative forms so small can be
used in its comparative and superlative
form as and when required
all right now let's take a look at a
little I am a little fat
now fat is an adjective right that means
that I'm not thin so I'm a little fat so
that means not too much but just a bit
okay fat is an adjective
little is modifying fat okay so if I'm
not very fat I'm little fat all right so
just a bit so you're it is modifying in
my next example he is a little tired so
tired again is an adjective that
describes someone of not being fresh so
I'm a little tired can I say or can I
say he is a small tire no we say a
little tired
so you're we are using little to modify
an adjective
all right friends so these are the
